questions.text: A 2-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician for the evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 2 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman in a birthing center. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the second half of the pregnancy. The newborn weighed 3700 g (8 lb 2.5 oz) at birth, and no congenital anomalies were noted. She currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). Examination of the newborn shows pink skin. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mucopurulent discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Polymerase chain reaction assay of conjunctival scraping confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is insufficient for the treatment of CC because of the high rates of concomitant upper respiratory tract colonization by Chlamydia trachomatis, which topical erythromycin cannot treat. Topical therapy with an erythromycin ointment administered shortly after delivery is recommended for prophylaxis of gonococcal conjunctivitis, which usually manifests at age 2–5 days with copious mucopurulent drainage.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated after flushing eyes with saline in cases of non-herpes viral conjunctivitis or chemical conjunctivitis, which generally resolves on its own. Chemical conjunctivitis occurs after topical silver nitrate administration and typically manifests within a day of birth and resolves after 4–5 days. Nonherpetic viral conjunctivitis is commonly unilateral with mucopurulent discharge.

C) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes infections. Herpetic neonatal conjunctivitis manifests with unilateral or bilateral lid edema, moderate conjunctival injection, and nonpurulent, serosanguinous discharge within 1–2 weeks after birth. Other signs include vesicles on the skin surrounding the eye and corneal epithelial involvement with dendritic or geographic ulcers. In this neonate, who has clinical features of CC, intravenous acyclovir would not be helpful.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is effective against neisserial conjunctivitis, not against chlamydial infections. Neisserial conjunctivitis typically manifests 2–7 days after birth with profuse bilateral purulent drainage and prominent eyelid swelling. This patient's mucopurulent discharge and mild swelling that developed almost 2 weeks after birth are more consistent with CC.

E) CORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is the treatment of choice for neonates with CC as it provides systemic Chlamydia trachomatis coverage, given the high rates of concomitant upper respiratory tract colonization in patients with CC. These benefits are generally considered to outweigh the increased risk of developing infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) associated with the medication, which is more common in newborns < 2 weeks old. Infants should still be closely monitored for any signs of IHPS, such as nonbilious vomiting and irritability when feeding. See “Overview of neonatal conjunctivitis” table.

The CDC recommends chlamydia screening for all pregnant women < 25 years of age (and those over 25 years of age if at increased risk) and retesting during the third trimester because neither oral nor topical antibiotic therapy is effective for the prevention of CC.

F) INCORRECT:

A silver nitrate solution was formerly instilled into the eyes of neonates as a prophylaxis against gonococcal conjunctivitis (Crede prophylaxis). However, silver nitrate was later found to be toxic to the conjunctiva and thus cause chemical conjunctivitis. Today, silver nitrate is no longer used prophylactically or therapeutically in the US and topical antibiotics are used instead.
questions.hint: Chlamydial conjunctivitis (CC) typically occurs in newborns 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with watery or mucopurulent discharge.

questions.text: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to the physician because of a red, irritated eye with yellow discharge. She was born via vaginal delivery at 39 weeks' gestation to a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother had an unmedicated delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. The mother had not seen her gynecologist since her first prenatal visit. The newborn's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 73/53 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. There is no corneal ulceration or evidence of keratitis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

choices.text: Oral erythromycin administered to the infant
IV ceftriaxone administered to the infant
Topical erythromycin administered to the infant
Oral doxycycline administered to the mother
Oral amoxicillin administered to the mother

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is not indicated as either prophylaxis or treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice in infants with NGC. However, ceftriaxone is not used for NGC prophylaxis.

C) CORRECT:

Topical erythromycin ointment should be applied within 1 hour of birth to prevent NGC. In most states in the US, prophylaxis against NGC is required by law. If left untreated, NGC may result in corneal scarring and blindness. After confirming NGC (using culture and Gram stain or PCR), systemic treatment with either an IV or IM third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) is indicated. In addition, the eyes should be flushed with saline until the discharge clears.
Image Description:

The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline may be administered to treat mothers of newborns who have newborn conjunctivitis due to an infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. However, administration of oral doxycycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis in pregnant women and, therefore, help prevent chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis (CNC). However, CNC typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is more consistent with NGC. Amoxicillin is not the first-line treatment for infection with Neisseria gonorrhea and, therefore, would have not prevented this newborn's NGC.
questions.hint: This patient presents with conjunctival injection and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge 2 days after birth, all of which are consistent with neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis (NGC). NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.

questions.text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Silver nitrate exposure can lead to chemical conjunctivitis, which usually manifests in the 1st day of life with mild watery discharge and conjunctival injections. Discharge and eyelid swelling was observed in this patient 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults and typically presents with unilateral conjunctival injection, chemosis, and thick purulent discharge. This patient has watery eye discharge. Moreover, Staphylococcus aureus is not a common cause of conjunctivitis in neonates.

C) CORRECT:

Chlamydial conjunctivitis, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, typically manifests at 5–14 days after birth with watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge in addition to mild eyelid swelling, as seen in this patient. Oral erythromycin is the treatment for chlamydial conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal conjunctivitis, which is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically manifests 2–7 days after delivery with profuse, purulent, ocular discharge in addition to a pronounced eyelid swelling. This patient, meanwhile, has a mild eyelid swelling and watery discharge observed 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis in neonates. It typically manifests within the first 14 days of life with nonpurulent, ocular discharge, corneal ulceration, and periocular vesicles. This patient lacks corneal ulceration and periocular vesicles, which make this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: A gram stain of this patient's discharge would yield a negative result.

questions.text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the office for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Silver nitrate exposure can lead to chemical conjunctivitis, which usually manifests in the 1st day of life with mild watery discharge and conjunctival injections. Discharge and eyelid swelling was observed in this patient 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

This patient has watery eye discharge. Moreover, Staphylococcus aureus is not a common cause of conjunctivitis in neonates.

Gonococcal conjunctivitis, which is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically manifests 2–7 days after delivery with profuse, purulent, ocular discharge in addition to a pronounced eyelid swelling. This patient, meanwhile, has a mild eyelid swelling and watery discharge observed 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis in neonates. It typically manifests within the first 14 days of life with nonpurulent, ocular discharge, corneal ulceration, and periocular vesicles. This patient lacks corneal ulceration and periocular vesicles, which make this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: A gram stain of this patient's discharge would yield a negative result.

The mother had an unmedicated vaginal delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

choices.text: Oral erythromycin administered to the infant
IV ceftriaxone administered to the infant
Topical erythromycin administered to the infant
Oral doxycycline administered to the mother
Oral amoxicillin administered to the mother

Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is not indicated as either prophylaxis or treatment.

Topical erythromycin ointment should be applied within 1 hour of birth to prevent NGC. In most states in the US, prophylaxis against NGC is required by law. In addition, the eyes should be flushed with saline until the discharge clears.

However, CNC typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is more consistent with NGC. Amoxicillin is not the first-line treatment for infection with Neisseria gonorrhea and, therefore, would have not prevented this newborn's NGC.

NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.

questions.text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to your clinic for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the third trimester. On examination, the newborn has watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis in neonates. It typically manifests within the first 14 days of life with nonpurulent, ocular discharge, corneal ulceration, and periocular vesicles. This patient lacks corneal ulceration and periocular vesicles, which make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Silver nitrate exposure can lead to chemical conjunctivitis, which usually manifests in the 1st day of life with mild watery discharge and conjunctival injections. Discharge and eyelid swelling was observed in this patient 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults and typically presents with unilateral conjunctival injection, chemosis, and thick purulent discharge. This patient has watery eye discharge. Moreover, Staphylococcus aureus is not a common cause of conjunctivitis in neonates.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal conjunctivitis, which is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically manifests 2–7 days after delivery with profuse, purulent, ocular discharge in addition to a pronounced eyelid swelling. This patient, meanwhile, has a mild eyelid swelling and watery discharge observed 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Chlamydial conjunctivitis, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, typically manifests at 5–14 days after birth with watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge in addition to mild eyelid swelling, as seen in this patient. Oral erythromycin is the treatment for chlamydial conjunctivitis.

Key learning point: Chlamydial conjunctivitis in newborns typically presents 5–14 days after birth with watery or mucopurulent discharge and mild eyelid swelling, and is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
questions.hint: A gram stain of this patient's discharge would yield a negative result.

questions.text: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to your clinic with a red, irritated right eye and yellow discharge. The mother had an unmedicated vaginal delivery at home, and the newborn did not receive any routine postpartum medications. On ophthalmic examination, there is eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. Which one of the following is most likely to have prevented this condition?

choices.text: Oral erythromycin administered to the newborn.
Topical ocular gentamicin administered to the newborn.
Intramuscular ceftriaxone administered to the mother.
Topical intravaginal silver nitrate administered to the mother.
Oral doxycycline administered to the mother.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient’s presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is no longer recommended for prevention or treatment. Although it was once used prophylactically, its use was discontinued after links to hypertrophic pyloric stenosis emerged.

B) INCORRECT:

Because of its high risk of chemical conjunctivitis, the Canadian Paediatric Society advises against using gentamicin ointment or povidone‑iodine for neonatal conjunctivitis prophylaxis. In provinces or territories that still mandate ocular prophylaxis, erythromycin ointment should be used.

C) CORRECT:

All pregnant individuals in Canada should be screened for gonorrhea at their first prenatal visit in the first trimester and again in the third trimester. For the prevention of neonatal gonococcal and chlamydial NGC, the emphasis has shifted from routine universal ocular prophylaxis to maternal screening and treatment. If a mother tests positive for gonorrhea, IM or IV ceftriaxone is administered to treat the infection and prevent neonatal transmission. The Canadian Pediatric Society advises against routine neonatal ocular topical prophylaxis due to increasing antibiotic resistance and the risk of chemical conjunctivitis from certain agents (e.g., silver nitrate, gentamicin, povidone-iodine). However, in some provinces where universal ocular prophylaxis is still legally mandated, erythromycin ointment should be used.

Untreated NGC can cause corneal scarring and blindness. This newborn with gonococcal NGC requires a single IM or IV dose of a third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime). If the mother was not screened during pregnancy but tests positive for gonorrhea postpartum, the newborn should have a conjunctival culture for N. gonorrhoeae and receive a single empirical dose of a third-generation cephalosporin even if the newborn is asymptomatic. If postpartum chlamydia testing is positive, a wait-and-watch approach is preferred over routine ocular culture and empirical treatment for asymptomatic newborns.

Key learning point: Infectious neonatal conjunctivitis is best prevented through routine prenatal screening and adequate maternal treatment.
Image Description:

The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

D) INCORRECT:

Maternal genital infection is the primary risk factor for infectious neonatal conjunctivitis, but no clinical trial has shown that intrapartum vaginal silver nitrate prevents infectious NGC. Although used prophylactically in the past, ocular silver nitrate causes a high rate of chemical conjunctivitis and is no longer recommended for routine administration in neonates.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline may be administered to treat mothers of newborns who have newborn conjunctivitis due to an infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. However, administration of oral doxycArticles (27)ycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.
questions.hint: This patient presents with conjunctival injection and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge 2 days after birth, all of which are consistent with neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis (NGC). NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.

questions.text: A 10-day-old infant is brought to the ED by parents who report eye swelling and thick discharge for the past 2 days. The infant was delivered at home by a doula and this is the infant's first interaction with healthcare professionals. The mother states she was told she had chlamydia during pregnancy but elected to use herbal remedies as she did not have symptoms and thought antibiotics might harm the fetus. Vital signs are BP, 72/40 mm Hg; P, 142; R, 40; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Examination reveals bilateral conjunctival injection with copious mucopurulent discharge. What is the most appropriate empiric treatment while awaiting culture results?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is effective prophylaxis but does not adequately treat established chlamydial infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is active against anaerobic bacteria and protozoa but has no role in treating neonatal conjunctivitis. The typical pathogens in this age group are Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, neither of which is effectively treated with metronidazole. Choosing this agent would leave the infection untreated and allow progression to systemic disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis, which usually presents earlier (2–5 days of life) with profuse purulent discharge and risk of corneal perforation. The timing and maternal history of chlamydia make gonorrhea less likely as the causative agent.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Neonatal chlamydial conjunctivitis typically presents 5–14 days after birth with mucopurulent discharge. Systemic treatment with oral erythromycin is indicated to eradicate infection and prevent complications such as chlamydial pneumonia. Topical therapy alone is inadequate.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones are used for adult bacterial conjunctivitis but are not recommended in neonates. They do not treat systemic chlamydial infection and would be inappropriate empiric therapy in this case.
